elements.label: Attribute
elements.description: Attributes are semanti tags

elements.label: Object Type
elements.description: Types of information

elements.label: Organization
elements.description: An established entity such as a university or company

elements.label: Member
elements.description: People who are verified members of a group or event

elements.label: Place
elements.description: Places are locations of interest, geographical spots.

elements.label: Group
elements.description: A online or in-person community that you can join

elements.label: Solution
elements.description: Answers or fixes to problems

elements.label: Resource
elements.description: Something that can be used to solve a problem

elements.label: Section
elements.description: Distinct parts of a document or website

elements.label: Framework
elements.description: A framework is a structured collection of related sectors or categories used to organize and analyze data or pursue a process. By providing a process of narrowing focus, it can help spark inspiration and generate, evaluate and prioritize ideas. Frameworks can also be used to guide decision-making, communicate complex ideas, and assist attainment of a specific goal or objective.

elements.label: Idea
elements.description: An idea or suggestion

elements.label: Air Pollution
elements.description:
The emission of aerosols (small particles) has a negative impact on the health of species. It can also affect precipitation and cloud formation.

The nine ecological ceilings of Doughnut Economics are from the planetary boundaries put forward by a group of Earth-system scientists led by Johan Rockström and Will Steffen.

elements.label: Organizations
elements.description: An established entity or formal body of people with a particular purpose, especially a business, society, association, etc.

elements.label: Biodiversity Loss
elements.description:
Economic activity may cause a reduction in the number and variety of species. This makes ecosystems more vulnerable and may lower their capacity of sustaining life and providing ecosystem services.

The nine ecological ceilings of Doughnut Economics are from the planetary boundaries put forward by a group of Earth-system scientists led by Johan Rockström and Will Steffen.

elements.label: Groups
elements.description: A set of people, organizations, or things which are considered together because they have something in common. Also, a type of Space created in Catalist to bring together two or more people for a shared experience based on common values, intentions, or topics of interest.

elements.label: Resources
elements.description: A resource refers to all that is available virtually or in our environment which are technologically accessible, economically feasible and culturally sustainable and help us to satisfy our needs and wants.

elements.label: Members
elements.description: A list of members (non-user) of a group. This could be a list of people in your groups CRM

elements.summary: Systems Transformation Catalyst working on bioregional resilience & regeneration as Senior Director at r3.0 (Redesign for Resilience & Regeneration)
elements.What do you appreciate most about this p: From my short time knowing Bill, I can tell that he's supportive of new ideas and exploring possibilities
elements.If you know them, how did you meet this: At my first meeting with the Connecticut River Valley Bioregional Collaborative
elements.label: Bill Baue (Sage)
Alliance for the Mystic River Watershed

elements.address: 270 N Colebrook Rd, Norfolk, CT 06058, USA
elements.summary: a 501 (c)(3) organized and operated for scientific research and preservation of land and natural resources. Our aim is to protect lands in Norfolk and Colebrook, Connecticut.
elements.description:
OUR MISSION

The goals of Aton Forest are:

· To preserve, protect and increase the lands of Aton Forest , Norfolk , Connecticut.

· To manage AF lands as
  a) Natural Areas, kept as free as possible from human	interference; and
  b) Semi-natural Management Areas, where human	manipulation may be appropriate.

· To conduct scientific research, especially interpretive, long-term, low-key Natural History and Total Landscape Ecosystem studies inspired by Dr. Frank E. Egler, on the lands of AF and elsewhere.

· To conduct conservation education activities based on ecological science.

· To preserve and make use of Dr. Egler ’s written records, including research notes, manuscripts,correspondence, and publication collections.

· To preserve and manage portions of Dr. Egler ’s house and some of its contents as a museum.
elements.label: Aton Forest

elements.summary: Using as the "RKC"s "Patterns" entity type.
elements.label: Domains and Content

elements.summary: One of the Triads
elements.description:
The British sociologist Raymond Williams once wrote, “Culture is ordinary.” We could say much the same about commoning. It is terribly ordinary. Commoning is what common people decide for themselves in their specific circumstances if they want to get along with each other and produce as much wealth for everyone as possible. If commoning can be considered a way of life or a type of culture, then it provides what any culture must — “meaning both in a formal and in a deeply existential sense,” as art sociologist Pascal Gielen writes.1 Modern societies have largely forgotten about commoning. Therefore, showcasing its elemental dailyness opens the door for seeing how the commons can provide a platform for effective alternatives to capitalism.

We start our explorations with the Social Life of commoning because its motifs constitute the core of any commons while also manifesting in the two other spheres, Provisioning and Peer Governance.
. . .
In modern times, market capitalism and its categories of thought have more or less mandated how we will behave, invest, organize institutions, and so forth, by presuming that human beings are basically selfish, materialistic, utility-maximizing individuals. No wonder commoning, with its different insights about human beings, is so often seen as strange. It has been eclipsed by the shiny cultural mindscape of modernity.

And yet, the way commoning catalyzes change is clear: the more you align yourself with a commons worldview and the more you practice commoning, the more you learn how to become a commoner. This, in turn, has sweeping ramifications for economics, politics, and culture. The patterns that comprise the Social Life of Commoning are specific forms of cooperation, sharing, and ways that people relate to each other. One could say that a commons arises when the patterns of Social Life reach a sufficient density of practice, threshold of self-organization, and continuity to express themselves as a coherent social institution.


Online Chapter: [The Social Life of Commoning](https://freefairandalive.org/read-it/#4)
elements.label: Social Life

elements.summary: one of the Spheres of the Triad of Commoning Patterns
elements.description:
Commoning may be rooted in a variety of social outlooks and behaviors, as we saw in Chapter Four. But can it govern? Can it do so better than existing governments? Can it coordinate more effectively and better than the market? . . .

The dynamics of peer governance at the cellular level of everyday practices matter because they provide regularity and stability to a commons. They also help us learn how to devise larger structures such as federated commons, commons-friendly law and policy, infrastructures, and commons-public partnerships, as we will see in later chapters. Here, we explore ten dynamics of Peer Governance that tend to be present in effective commons. The first seven revolve around interpersonal and social relationships. The final three involve commons-based methods for dealing with property, money, and markets.
. . .


Online Chapter: [Peer Governance Through Commoning](https://freefairandalive.org/read-it/#5)
elements.label: Peer Governance

elements.summary: one of the Spheres of the Triad of Commoning Patterns
elements.description:
Commoning is at heart an act of social self-organization and constant learning whose central purpose is to help people meet needs by producing things or services together. (We prefer to use the word “**provisioning**” as a nonmarket version of “production.”)

. . .

Online Chapter: [Provisioning Through Commons](https://freefairandalive.org/read-it/#6)
elements.label: Provisioning

elements.summary: author, activist, blogger and consultant who spends a lot of time exploring the commons as a new paradigm of economics, politics and culture.
elements.label: David Bollier

elements.summary: An interactive visual index to Bollier's and Helfrich's Triad of Commoning Patterns
elements.label: The Visual Triad of Commoning Patterns

elements.summary:
The Connecticut River Conservancy (CRC) restores and advocates for clean water, healthy habitats, and resilient communities to support a diverse and thriving watershed.
​
Through collaborative partnerships in New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, and Connecticut, CRC leads and supports science-based efforts for natural and life-filled rivers from source to sea.
elements.label: Connecticut River Conservancy

elements.address: 15 Bank Row a, Greenfield, MA 01301, USA
elements.summary: a non-profit environmental organization dedicated to the stewardship, protection, and restoration of one of Massachusetts' and Vermont’s most beautiful rivers. We engage in volunteer-assisted monitoring of water quality, river clean-up days, school programs and watershed education, mini-grants for school river projects, maintenance of the Mohican-Mohawk Trail, river restoration, advocating for responsible public use, and protection of the river from threats to its health and scenic quality. DRWA's newest projects include working with communities throughout the watershed to seek National Wild and Scenic River designation.
elements.label: Deerfield River Watershed Association (DRWA)

elements.summary:
Here we are using "Meme" as a meta-space to encompass all the ideas, concepts, entities, frameworks, classification and categorization schemes, etc.  that might be of interest to this knowledge commoning initiative.

All the entries in this Catalist "section" are at a definitional level, i.e. the meta level ~ i.e. the entries will not represent instances of "tangibles", (e.g., humans, more-than-humans, groups / communities / initiatives / organizations, places / spaces / regions), for which see the other sections of this space.
elements.label: Memes

elements.summary: One of the Social Life Sphere's Patterns
elements.description:
***How does a group become coherent and mutually aligned?***

Commons rarely start with shared values and intentions. Instead, they are forged as people of diverse talents and temperaments share experiences. Only if commoners accept the diversity of the group and are willing to align themselves with one another, developmental processes that include routines, reflections, and rituals, participants can cultivate shared purpose and values.

* In community supported agriculture (CSA), the common intention is to grow and share healthy, fresh food. A sense of shared purpose arises as people participate in (for example) farm festivals, vegetable processing workshops, or shared field work.

* When members of the Commons-Institute (Germany) meet, there are evenings of storytelling. People are asked: to explain, "How did you come to Commons and ultimately to the Institute?" Stories are vivid and memorable, and help connect people with each other.
-----------------------------------------
For more about local communities and how they are turning to CSAs and other ways to reduce their dependence on Big Agriculture and enhance their resilience, see **The Commoner's Catalog of Changemaking**'s section on ***[Relocalized Food](https://kumu.io/vincentarena/nebkc-catalist#commoning-exploration-map/1738170138536x592869585929633800?focus=%231738169295304x101158222616592380%20out%201)***.
elements.label: Cultivate Shared Purpose and Values

elements.summary: The Memetic Activation Platform (MAP) is an open-ended, de-centralized, computing and application services platform whose audacious goal is to foster the emergence of self-organizing, evolutionary transformation at personal, interpersonal, organizational, inter-organizational and, ultimately, global levels.
elements.label: Memetic Activation Platform

elements.description:

elements.One Page Bio: Committed to leveraging my 30+ year tech career to support those on the forefront of the evolutionary shift towards a world that works for all life.
elements.label: Steve Melville

elements.summary:
a meme is a self-replicating, mutating and re-combining unit of culture carrying ideas, symbols, or practices that can be transmitted from one mind to another through writing, speech, gestures, rituals, or other imitable phenomena.

[a primary sub-type of the MAP's Holon Type]
elements.label: Meme

elements.summary:
An agent is any entity with the capacity to sense and respond to its environment.

[a primary sub-type of the MAP's Holon Type]
elements.label: Agent

elements.summary:
a resource is: 1) something that is available for use or that can be used for support or help.  2) an available supply that can be drawn on when needed.

[a primary sub-type of the MAP's Holon Type]
elements.description:
*How can we communicate effectively?*

Self-responsible communication means honestly and respectfully expressing one's own needs and limits. This requires appropriate times and circumstances as well as a sense of one's own demeanor and tone in communication. In direct exchanges, active listening and compassionate speaking are important. With individual and collective self-awareness, norms of communication can be regularly reviewed and improved.

 - Communication rules are agreed upon in both digital and analog spaces. Suitable moderation methods – such as 'talking stick' rounds – allow all participants to speak without time pressure or tyranny of the loudest ones.

 - [Nonviolent communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonviolent_Communication) supports the implementation of this pattern.

 - A good motto is: Speak spontaneously and from the heart. and listen from the heart.

**new pattern from Patterning cards ~ November 2024**
elements.label: Resource

elements.summary:
Each service provides the means for realizing value flows between agents (horizontal value flow) as well as the means for helping to realize some desired ends (vertical flow). 

MAP Services consist of an offer, an implementation, zero or more agreements (accepted offers) and zero or more events. 

[a primary sub-type of the MAP's Holon Type]
elements.label: Service

elements.summary: From the MAP ~ Memetic Activation Platform
elements.description: ![MAP Holon Type - w:o name.png](//ee90efb54bd21b2eb02d2cf66c18cf93.cdn.bubble.io/f1737299864098x601889687142315600/MAP%20Holon%20Type%20-%20w%3Ao%20name.png)
elements.label: Holon Type

elements.description:
*How can we communicate effectively?*

Self-responsible communication means honestly and respectfully expressing one's own needs and limits. This requires appropriate times and circumstances as well as a sense of one's own demeanor and tone in communication. In direct exchanges, active listening and compassionate speaking are important. With individual and collective self-awareness, norms of communication can be regularly reviewed and improved.

 - Communication rules are agreed upon in both digital and analog spaces. Suitable moderation methods – such as 'talking stick' rounds – allow all participants to speak without time pressure or tyranny of the loudest ones.

 - [Nonviolent communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonviolent_Communication) supports the implementation of this pattern.

 - A good motto is: Speak spontaneously and from the heart. and listen from the heart.

**new pattern from Patterning cards ~ November 2024**
elements.label: Show empathy & self-responsibility in communication

elements.description:
*How are conflicts addressed?*

It is important to have protected spaces in which conflicts can be made visible and their causes understood. An attitude of respect and mutual concern is critical. Complaints focus on concrete behaviors or statements, not individuals. Criticism is balanced with expressions of respect and personal appreciation. An attitude of respect and mutual concern is critical so that relationships can be changed and not destroyed. Anyhow, in some instances separations may be the best option.

 - At the Cecosesola cooperative (Venezuela), concrete behaviors are openly and substantially criticized in group settings, but the choice of words and tone remain respectful. After conflict situations, for example, a hug conveys the message: Whatever our disagreement, I see you as a human being.

 - Systemic coaching, mediations and 'Constellations' workshops can address conflicts while preserving relationships.
elements.label: Preserve Relationships in Addressing Conflicts

elements.summary:
The Triad of Commoning is a framework which points to the idea that commoners are engaged in “world-making in a pluriverse” because that phrase captures the core purpose of commoning: the creation of peer-governed, context-specific systems for free, fair, and sustainable lives. 

At the heart of the Framework is what we call The Triad — the three interconnected Spheres of Social Life, Peer Governance and Provisioning.  Or, in more conventional terms: the social, the institutional, and the economic spheres.
elements.description:
We find it useful to structure our thinking around these realms, which doesn’t mean that they are separate and distinct. Each sphere of the Triad simply provides a different perspective for looking at the same phenomena. Each is deeply interconnected with the others, as the accompanying image suggests.

. . .

Online Chapter: [The Triad of Commoning](https://freefairandalive.org/read-it/#part2)
elements.label: The Triad of Commoning

elements.summary: The catalog showcases the art, culture, and politics of commoning— the practices of talking with each other, coordinating work, experimenting, and figuring out solutions to shared challenges and how to make them local, distributed, and fair. It turns out that building a better future does not necessarily require that we go through the narrow channel of conventional politics and policy, though both surely have important roles to play. Commons-based solutions can originate right now, with us, where we live. They can even emerge, sometimes, in partnership with state authorities who understand the logic and ethos of commoning.
elements.description: [[youtube/3HvucY2UymM]]
elements.label: The Commoner"s Catalog for Changemaking

elements.summary: To reduce their dependence on Big Agriculture and enhance their resilience, many local communities are embracing community supported agriculture, community land trusts, agroecology, the principles of Slow Food, urban farming, and other types of relocalized food.
elements.description: ![ Relocalized Food.png](//ee90efb54bd21b2eb02d2cf66c18cf93.cdn.bubble.io/f1738176045063x160637034504915070/%20Relocalized%20Food.png)
elements.label: Relocalized Food

elements.summary: An estimated two billion people in poor, rural regions depend on the commoning of forests, fisheries, irrigation water, and other natural systems for their daily life. Often denigrated as premodern, these commons nonetheless tend to be more eco-friendly and fair-minded than markets.
elements.label: Subsistence Commons

elements.summary: Contrary to standard economic theory, giving away one’s time or property can be a powerful source of value, as seen in gift economies of artists, scholars, Indigenous peoples, and open-source software programmers. Gifts elicit and sustain collaboration, sociability, ethical behavior, and trust.
elements.label: Gift Economies

elements.summary: One of the Peer Governance sphere's patterns
elements.description:
***How do commoners make decisions and on what basis?***

To ensure that decisions are based on the best information available, and that outcomes are seen as fair and wise, all participants must have opportunities to make their wishes and concerns known and respectfully heard. In contrast to majority-rule voting, decision-making in commons strives to avoid the creation of systematic winners and losers, or factional blocs.

 - In **[Sociocracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociocracy)**, a process of "talking in rounds" with the goal of obtaining wide consent for decisions, but not necessarily consensus. The point is to reach decisions that are _"good enough for now, safe enough to try"_.  See also:  _[SoFA's Visual Thesaurus](https://kumu.io/rmattlage/sofa-visual-thesaurus#sofa-visual-thesaurus?focus=%23sofa-thesaurus-domain%20out%202,%20%23principles-and-values%20out%201)_

 - In **[Systemic Consensing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systemic_Consensing)**, people are asked to express their level of resistance, and not just a yes or no answer. Experience shows: The less resistance, the greater the long-term acceptance.

 - A specific time for revisiting a decision can be set.

 - It is often useful to expand the decision options beyond pro & con. On the Quaker Continuum, people can take six different positions on an issue: from full support to total rejection.
elements.label: Assure Consent in Decision Making
